segments.text: This is an interview with Major General Thomas Darling by Tara Pressnell on April 25, 1991 at General Darling's office concerning Vietnam.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that alright with you?
Yes, that's fine.
For the purpose of this interview, could you please give me your date and place of birth and formal educational background?
I was born April 30, 1932, in Abilene, Texas.
I came to Texas A&M in the fall of 1950, graduated here in 1954, and went immediately into the Air Force.
While in the Air Force, I earned a Master of Science in Public Relations.
public administration from George Washington University, graduate of the Air Force Pilot School, the Air Command and Staff College, the Squadron Officer Force, and the Naval War College.
What unit were you with and where were you based in Southeast Asia?
And what was the mission of the unit that you were assigned to?
Well, I was a member of a provisional wing.
I forget even the number of that provisional wing.
located on the island of Guam.
Early in the war, when it was determined that they needed the B-52s for bombing in Vietnam, they started sending units on temporary duty to Guam.
We were all put in a wing called, like it was a 41-33rd Provisional Wing.
But it ended up with units from across the United States supplying elements to that provisional wing.
That's a common organization that was used in the Persian Gulf conflict.
Many of the Air Force units were assigned to a provisional wing, meaning a temporary wing for the duration of the war.
But I was a member of this provisional wing on the island of Guam.
elements from several other bases, stateside bases there when I was there.
Say again the last part of it.
What was the mission at the unit that you were assigned to?
The mission I was assigned to was to conduct iron bombing.
I wouldn't call it strategic bombing.
I guess it would be tactical bombing in support of ground troops,
in South Vietnam primarily.
What exactly were your responsibilities at Anderson Air Force Base in Guam?
I was a B-52 aircraft commander.
I had five other members of that crew and we were an integral unit.
We trained and worked together and we flew over together and we flew missions together as an integrated crew.
I was the aircraft commander, the one that was charged with the training, flying missions, the effectiveness of that crew, putting the bombs on the target, if you will.
Did you volunteer for duty in Vietnam?
Well, I went willingly.
You know, I was not given a chance to hold up my hand or sign something to say I wanted to go.
I was gone.
I was over there before that even really came in, really.

Later in the war, people had many opportunities to volunteer, and a lot of people did, but I was over there in early 1966 before, well, in the early stages of the program, so while I went willingly, I guess you'd say voluntarily, it really was not...
something that I had an opportunity to say whether I wanted to go or not.
How often were you flying combat missions in Southeast Asia?
We would fly at least every third day.
I was there for about 180 days during that time that I was assigned to the 4133rd Provisional Wing.
We would sometimes pull spare.
They had to spare each.
They provided at least two or three spare aircraft and crews for each day's mission.

If one of the airplanes that was scheduled to go couldn't make it for some reason, had a mechanical problem, couldn't take off, or had to abort and return, then a spare aircraft would be sent to take its place, a spare aircraft and crew.
So we pulled spare or actually flew a mission usually about every other day.
Did any of your missions originate from bases other than Guam?
I don't believe so.
We had to divert sometimes for weather, but I don't believe I actually flew a mission from any base other than on the island of Guam.
Now, later on in the war, other bases were brought in.
Thailand became a very popular base.
In fact, most of the sorties were launched from bases in Thailand rather than Guam.
Guam was such a distance away, it made it a very grueling mission.
It was a 12-hour mission at least and an 18- to 20-hour day, the time you consider pre-flight mission planning.
Briefings, takeoff, return, debriefing, and all of that.
So crews could only fly, and airplanes could only fly so many sorties in a given period of time.
So it was advantageous to move the bases closer in, move the bases closer in so that more sorties could be flown.
But that was a problem at Guam, just being such a great distance from the target area.
Would you describe in depth the typical combat mission in a B-52 from beginning to end?
Okay, I did a little of that, but let me start over.
Most of the missions that I flew, the takeoff was from 3 to 5 o'clock in the morning.
That was all designed to put us over the target area at the desired time.
But we would take off, well, we'd start with...
With a meal in the dining hall there, it would usually be three to four hours in advance of our takeoff time.
We'd eat a meal, and then we would go to our briefings.
Those would last 30 to 40 minutes.
We'd have the operations briefing, the weather briefing.
a lot of other briefings.
We'd have the individual cell briefings where each group of crews that were flying in a cell together would have their own briefings.
We'd always close with the chaplain, his comments and a prayer.
And then we would go to our airplanes, pre-flight those airplanes, and at a given time we would start engines and taxi out of position and take off.
And then, as I say, the takeoff was all 3 to 5 o'clock in the morning.
A lot of 4 o'clock takeoffs, I remember.
But we would take off, and it was about six hours en route to Vietnam, to the target area.
And en route to about three hours out, we'd conduct one aerial refueling, because we needed that fuel to get to the target area and back.
We'd usually meet a tanker out of the Kadena Air Base, which is located on the island of Okinawa.
The tankers would come up and we'd rendezvous with them and usually take on 100 to 120,000 pounds of fuel.
That would enable us to fly the mission through the tactics that were required at the return home.
Again, about a 12-hour, 12-and-a-half-hour mission.
But we were loaded with bombs, which limited the amount of fuel that you could have on board.
An airplane can only take off a certain weight.
We usually took off in the particular airplane that I flew at about 450,000 pounds.
And 60,000 pounds or so of that would be bombs.
So we couldn't
take off with all the fuel that the airplane would hold because with the bombs we would exceed the max weight that we could actually get airborne.
And on the island of Guam, which is very hot and humid, not a very good environment there for maximum performance from an airplane, a jet engine.
It's better performance in cool, dry conditions.
So we needed all the runway there to get off at the loads that we took off.

But anyway, back to where I started, we would get that refueling and then we would press on usually over, we would take off from Guam and head toward, generally in the direction of Okinawa, refuel and then from there head toward South Vietnam.
And usually we'd come in from over the South China Sea
And targets were from southern Vietnam, even bombed in Laos a couple of times.
And that would take us about six hours into the mission.
The bomb run was, of course, the most critical part of the mission.
to be lined up on the proper axis that they had planned for you to fly in on.
We had to have exact spacing and distance from the airplanes in front to the side of us.
But each crew had to make an individual drop.
That was the scheduled way to drop.
There were emergency ways where we could drop from the airplane in front of us in case we were having system malfunctions.
But generally, we dropped individually.
But these missions were all designed to achieve a certain pattern with bombs.
We were scheduled to drop inside of a box.
And we knew what that box was.
Of course, we tried hard to always make sure we were in that box.
One thing, we did not drop unless we had positive contact with the target that we were dropping on.
just to make random drops.
You had to be certain of what you were bombing or you didn't drop bombs.
That's very important.

But the run into the target from the coast would be a 30, 40 minute period, roughly from the time we coasted in, penetrated the area, and dropped our bombs, did our maneuvers, and returned to the coast.
But that was the critical period when everything became quite intense.
Then on the return flight, we'd fly straight back to the island of Guam, flying over the Philippines.
We'd usually fly at 43,000, 44,000 feet to conserve fuel by airplane, getting better fuel performance at higher altitudes.
So we had to do that to get home.
A lot of weather, usually both going and coming to skirt.
But we, again, tried to maintain the formation, the cell as we called it.
We took off in cell, we bombed in cell, we returned in cell, we landed in cell formation.
Again, a mission that usually was 12 to 12 and a half hours long, and after that we would
taxi and unload our equipment and go into a debriefing that was very extensive.
It took considerable time.
They asked us questions.
We had to fill out forms pertaining to the mission.
and what we encountered from radars to what we saw in the target area, any other things that we observed, the general intelligence fact-finding kind of debriefing that we went through.
Also, we had to be debriefed about the equipment on the airplane, the systems, what malfunctioned, any problems that we had.
A lot of paperwork to fill out, and that usually took
an hour and a half or so to do all of that.
And then we were free to go on in our barracks area if they don't want.
That's a typical mission.
At the time that you were flying combat missions, how much leeway and choosing targets were commanders given?
Very little.
There were
I can't recall a time that I had any leeway on the target that we were to bomb with maybe this exception.
If there was weather in the area that would preclude us from hitting the target, we might have been given secondary targets that we could go and strike.
But it was a matter of me determining the weather was too severe for us to
go to the original target, and we might have to go to an alternate target, which we'd already been given.
But we were not given the latitude to select the targets on our own.
That's not our option, at least not during the time that I was there.
In relation to that question, could you give specific examples of targets that Johnson or Nixon disapproved, and why?
That they disapproved?
You know, at my level, I really didn't know that.
I know that mission tasking sometimes at least appeared to come from back home somewhere.
And I know that the targets we struck were very, very
tightly controlled, and a lot of it was developed for reasons that we didn't even understand or weren't even aware of what all went into the selection of the targets.
As a young crew member, my job was to take a mission that I'd been assigned and go do that, and I really didn't understand or know how a lot of that came about.
But it was my feeling that a lot of that was determined at very high levels.
Did you receive training in Vietnamese culture before going to Vietnam?
Oh, a little bit.
Not very much.
Again, our going was kind of a hasty move.
The whole unity of the wing that I was assigned to back in the States was told on fairly short notice that we would be deploying.
Again, I was in the fairly early stages of the war.
So we really didn't have time to get a whole lot of indoctrination.
Of course, the other thing, I was flying missions from Guam, and I had very little contact with the enemy.
It was interesting, the missions that I flew were high altitude missions.
You couldn't really see things that well on the ground.
And we were bombing an enemy that essentially I couldn't see.
It was kind of an impersonal war, in that sense,
what I was doing.
What were your perceptions of the Vietnamese people as a whole and the leaders of the Army of the Republic of Vietnam?
Well, my impressions of the Vietnamese, again, I didn't have that much contact with them.
I did see them back in the States in places over the period of the war.
You know, I generally had...
in high regard for the Vietnamese that I encountered during those four years.
Again, I didn't encounter them day to day during the war because of where I was assigned.
The leaders of Vietnam, I don't know, it's hard to say.
Again, I wasn't, I was not that directly involved.
In your opinion, what was the overall morale of the unit that you were with?
And was there a difference in morale between the officers and the enlisted?
I'd say the morale of the unit I was assigned was very high.
Again, this was early in the war.
We were, I think, about the second B-52 wing involved in the war, the second deployment of B-52 wings.
Again, our morale was very high.
I think the professionalism was very good.
The performance was outstanding.
And I could cite many examples of what I could say was an outstanding performance by crews that I flew with.
As far as the officers listed any difference, I would say the morale was very high among both.
Again, we were in a little different situation.
We could fly combat missions and come home and sleep in air-conditioned quarters.
Food was good.
The thing that sort of got us down, I guess, toward the end was the continuation of long, grueling missions every second or third day that really, really wear one out.
How would you describe your assignment with the Strategic Air Command and did the activities of the command escalate with the warranty?
What was the first part?
How would you describe your assignment with the Strategic Air Command?
Well, that was kind of hard to answer because I spent 20 something years with the Strategic Air Command on and off again.
I started in that command, I always felt it was
a very professional organization.
I think it was the pace setter for the Air Force in terms of professionalism and performance for many years.
I think General May came in and helped set some very high standards.
It was very demanding.
Crews had to perform.
Again, I think the rest of the Air Force learned a lot from SAC in those early years.
No question in my mind about that.
I think the rest of the Air Force sort of caught up with SAC in later years.
But, you know, my regard for SAC was always very high.
I always felt that the standards were very high and that the people they had
and I think they still are.
But again, I think many of the SAC methods and standards were later adopted by the rest of the Air Force.
Standardization is a good example.
SAC in the early years had standardization programs that
They were almost foreign to the rest of the Air Force.
But today, most Air Force organizations have standardization programs that follow along the lines of what was learned at SAC many years ago.
The last part of the question was?
Did the activities of the command escalate with the war in Vietnam?
Oh, yes, very much.
More and more SAC units were added to the conflict.
At the end of the campaign, I can't even recall how many B-52s were involved, but it seemed to me like there was an order of 200, something like that.
But the Linebacker II operation in December 1972, I think was the thing that finally brought that conflict to an end.
Certainly that was a great escalation of efforts from what it was in the earlier years when I was there.
What is your understanding of the reasons that the United States got involved in Vietnam?
Well, I think in 1964, 65,
People thought, believed in the domino theory that the communists gobbled up one nation and another was in line to fall.
And I think most of us at that time felt that we need to draw the line, that we couldn't afford to give up South Vietnam to the communists.
They seemed aggressive and seemed to have the intent of trying to capture the world, if you would.
And they were determined they weren't going to be able to do that.
I think we really felt that the communist world was ready to take another country into their fold.
We didn't want them to do that.
And I think that's one of the key things that got us into the war.
Of course, there was
I think other things like shooting at a ship and that sort of thing that today seem questionable may be given as the exact reasons that we got into that war.
But I think generally we were determined that the Communists weren't going to take another country and move forward.
I understand that careerism and ticket punching are sometimes prevalent in the military, and officers serve in order to further their own self-interest.
Did you find that to be the case in Vietnam?
Well, again, I didn't find it the case in the unit that I was assigned to in 1966.
However, I would say that there was some of that that went on, perhaps a whole lot of it went on during the Vietnamese War.
I think there were a lot of people that went forward, get their ticket punched, as we say, thinking it was forever their career, and I think it did help some people.
Having that combat experience, I think, served a lot of people well in later jobs and responsibilities.
But I didn't observe that in the part of the war in the time period that I was there, not in the unit that I was assigned.
I think it became more prevalent in some services later on.
What did you think of the one-year tour of duties that were served in Vietnam?
Well, in hindsight, I think it was a big mistake.
I think we made the mistake of not utilizing our reserve forces, not having any kind of globalization effort.

I think the Persian Gulf War stands in the contrast where we learned the lesson of not getting into rotations but to mobilize and call up the forces we need and try to make sure we've had enough to do the job and get on with it and get it over with.
But I think back in Vietnam, Presidents then, Johnson, Nixon,
They wanted to have guns and butter both, as we say.
They wanted to fight the war and have everything fine back home and things going normal here.
And that was, I think, the term of the day.
A mistake in the final analysis.
The one-year tour, bad in a number of ways, in my opinion.
One, people have to be trained.
It takes a while to get them over there.
When they get there, they have to be indoctrinated.
They have to fly.
When I went there, we had to fly two missions that were supervised by experienced crews who'd already been through what we were going through before we could be turned loose to be on our own.
But there was a lot of in-country indoctrination training that had to go on.
It was some waste of time in the total scheme of things.
Then midway, people are looking for the end so they can go home or do something else.
But it caused a lack of continuity in planning and leadership and a lot of things.
I just think it's a big mistake.
We'd be much better off to have mobilized.
In your opinion, why was the United States not successful in the war in Vietnam?
Well, I think I'd say we were successful in the war, but maybe barely so.
We had a lot of battles that we lost a lot of people in.
I think we failed to understand the culture.
I think at least in the early years we thought that we did
drop a lot of firepower on them and they would knuckle under and come to see things as we did and it would respond accordingly.
But I think we found out there are a lot tougher people fighting in the jungles.
It was a lot more difficult than fighting in the sands and rock.
But the people
And it shouldn't have been any less to us.
I think it had been proven before even World War II.
Sometimes the more you bomb people, the more hurt you cause on them, the more determined they become.
They had thousands of reserves.
They were very good at hiding and doing harassing kind of things to us.
We could destroy trails and roads.
Two days later, they'd have them restored, and that seemed to be a surprise to us.
We never could quite figure out how they could do all this.
But they were very good at that.
We were fighting on their territory, something that, in their homeland, that they understood a lot better than we did, the jungles and the rivers and all of that.
But we never seemed to get that figured out until the end, I guess.
While we thought we could, again, exert enough power and force that would cause them to withdraw or surrender and back up and come to the peace table, it never happened until the end of the war.
I think one reason, and I know there are several other reasons we weren't as successful as we could have been,
We never really turned loose of everything.
We always seemed to fight with one hand behind our backs.
I think we're a little afraid that millions of the Chinese would come into the war.
I think today sometimes people have lost sight of the situation back then.
We were concerned about what the Russians and the Chinese would do if we went in with an all-out effort against the North Vietnamese.
What would the Chinese do?
Would they turn loose millions of Chinese troops to come down?
Would we be involved in something that we had no intentions of getting into or getting involved with?
How would we fight a major land war with millions of Chinese?
We were a little bit afraid of that.
How much effort would the Soviet Union provide?
We didn't know.
So we did fight a little bit restrained, not knowing what we might run up against, not wanting to alienate the Soviets too much.
I think that hurt us in the long run.
I think in hindsight we would have gone in there with a lot more force a lot sooner and probably ended that war on favorable terms for us.
But I think we have to realize that conditions were a little different in those times.
Contrast that again with Iraq.
We didn't have to worry about the Chinese or the Soviet Union.
The Soviet Union was essentially on our side and supporting the thing.
So we could go in with a free hand and dump half a million troops into the Persian Gulf in a few months without fear about what the Soviet Union was going to do.
That was not the case in Vietnam.
We had to worry about some other things.
And we didn't want to get into too big a war over there.
So I think that caused us to be a little restrained.
But again, in hindsight, had we marshalled the forces that we needed,
early on and gone in without holding back, I think we could have ended that thing a lot sooner.
What lessons did the U.S. Air Force learn from the Vietnam experience?
Well, some we've already touched on.
I'd say not only the Air Force, but all the military learned some lessons over there.
I think joining this is one thing that we weren't very good at back in those days.
services tended to do things by themselves.
We didn't have the command structure set up as well as it could have been.
I think, again, what we saw in the Persian Gulf is a good example of how jointness can work if you put certain commanders in charge.
You know, Schwarzkopf was in charge of the whole operation that got
minimum guidance from Washington.
He had a pretty free hand in selecting targets and letting commanders do their thing.
That was a lesson we learned in Vietnam.
All the good things I saw in the Persian Gulf were pretty much lessons we'd learned in Vietnam and carried them through well.
We didn't get in a war of attrition in the Persian Gulf.
I was in the state we made in Vietnam.
We just sort of counted the dead people every day to determine how well you're doing.
And those numbers were totally erroneous, exaggerated.
Sometimes it just didn't know and you can't know.
That was a mistake, but something we learned to not get into a war of attrition, counting dead bodies.
But putting air power under one commander, I think, was something we learned in Vietnam and something that was executed very well in the Persian Gulf.
And one Air Force three-star general was in charge of all of the air forces, all elements of our power in the Persian Gulf.
And I think that has set a precedent that we'll stick to for some time to come.
But we had too many  we were just too fractured, I think, in Vietnam from a lot of standpoints.
Other lessons, mobilization is one that I mentioned.
To call up the forces you need and put them there for the period that you need them rather than getting into this rotation box.
That hurt us terribly in Vietnam.
Particularly in the services like the Army and the Marine Corps
that didn't require a lot of foot soldiers on the ground, a lot of privates, if you would.
And they were drafting these people and giving them a minimum amount of training, sending them over there.
They didn't want to be there after a while.
And, you know, all the horror stories of Vietnam evolved from that kind of thing.
The fraggies and the drug, you know,
culture almost started during that period.
Just a lot of bad things, I think, from a rotation policy that called for a lot of grantees to be sent over there.
We weren't really committed to the effort.
I think we learned that we need more stability in units rather than just a flow of people going in and out of a unit.
It's been studied and proven for years that people will die for a unit that they feel very attached to when they wouldn't for any other reason.
They'll die for a friend or a buddy that's very close to them.
But when you're rotating people in and out of a unit, there's no real attachment to each other.
I think that was a good lesson from Vietnam.
Working in unified ways
Again, it relates to the jointness theory.
I think it was a good lesson.
We certainly improved there how to work together.
Another thing we learned was that responsibility, well, those who execute the war have to be put down as low a level as you can do that.
The field commanders have to be given some authority to do certain things.
Everything cannot be controlled from back home.
I know that you had many unforgettable experiences while in Vietnam, but is there any one in particular that you would like to relate to me?
Well, I guess one of the, again, this happened in the spring of 1966, which was pretty early in the war.
But flying B-52s there was still a pretty new thing.
I remember we got a mission that we were told one day that the next day that we were going to North Vietnam to bomb, which
presented a much more serious threat to us as a big airplane, something we were quite apprehensive about, as it turned out, and we actually were over in Laos.
But it again was a much more hostile environment than what we had been flying earlier missions into.
We were concerned about that, but they had this big
the trail that the Vietnamese were using to transport equipment, supplies, and people down.
But there was a big cliff area there, as I understood it, that was going to us.
Down at the bottom was a valley that, again, a lot of the equipment was flowing down to south Vietnam.
But they wanted to send the B-52s in there to sort of level that cliff, fill in the valley, and shut off
with the supply of equipment and supplies into South Vietnam.
And we took it as a big challenge, and it was the biggest mission flown up until that point of the war.
And I remember we were tasked to fly 30 B-52s and 30 KC-135s, taking off at one-minute intervals, all launching from Guam during the night hours.
something that we were very keyed up for.
You know, I can liken it to one of the early missions of the troops.
It was like the first night that they flew into Iraq.
It's kind of unknown territory and you don't know what threats you're going to run into.
We suspected that the fighters would be after us and some SAMs would be after us and that proved true to some extent.
But again,
We all took that mission very seriously with a great deal of apprehension of the unknown.
But I remember we took off that night, and the most amazing thing to me was that we were scheduled to launch 60 airplanes at one-minute intervals.
And I'm talking big airplanes.
I'm not talking F-15s or something like that, little fighters.
But to put together
a 60 ship launch at one minute intervals is a pretty fantastic thing.
But that night we, in total darkness, launched those 60 airplanes exactly on the hack when they depart.
That may not seem such a tremendous thing to one that's not that familiar with aviation
big airplanes, nighttime, carrying large loads of bombs.
But I considered it the greatest thing that I observed.
Again, all 60 of those airplanes took off, performed their mission, and all returned.
We did have some SAMs, and I remember listening over the radio that night.
I remember a couple of fighter planes were shot down by SAMs, and I heard and saw some of that.
But again, all of the weapons were delivered and every airplane flew its mission as prescribed and all returned as planned.
And I think that's a pretty amazing feat in aviation.
Unfortunately, we dropped the bombs and thought we'd done a pretty good job.
But we were told within just a few days that they would reopen up the supply lines through that same valley that we thought we would wipe down.
So while it was a great feat, it was a great disappointment too because we didn't really do what, although we cratered the cliff and filled in the valley and all of that,
The photo by recce planes in the next few days showed that they had thousands of Vietnamese in there working and had it all open again in a few days.
So no great feat, but really a disappointing kind of thing, but also showed the number of problems that we faced with that terrain for those people.
Thank you very much.
